headline.main: In Nursing Homes, an Epidemic of Poor Dental Hygiene

docs.abstract: The lack of daily oral care in nursing facilities is almost universally overlooked, experts say, and studies suggest that it may contribute to pneumonia, a leading killer of institutionalized older people.
docs.snippet: The lack of daily oral care in nursing facilities is almost universally overlooked, experts say, and studies suggest that it may contribute to pneumonia, a leading killer of institutionalized older people.

docs.lead_paragraph: KOURKOUTAS--Kiki N., nee Skaphidas, 88, of Denville, NJ, died peacefully on July 31, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Nicholas for 59 years, devoted mother of Margo and Vickie, respected mother-in-law of Dennis and Nick, and grandmother of Katie and Dean. Born in Athens, Greece, Kiki graduated from Russell Sage College in Troy, NY in 1948 with a BS degree. Later in 1953, as one of the first Greek Fulbright scholarship award- ees in the United States she completed a MS in Nutrition from Columbia University's Teachers College. A Registered Dietitian, Kiki directed the dietary department of what is today's Jewish Home Lifecare's Bronx Campus for seventeen years -- a job she relished. During retirement, Kiki divided her time between nursing home dietary consulting and philanthropic work with the Greek Orthodox Ladies Philoptochos Society. Given her appreciation for the opportunities bestowed her, donations may be made in her honor to Greek United States Fulbright Foundation, account #0019 2057 7117, Bank of America, POB 31900, Tampa, FL 33631-3900, or to www.stmichaelshome.org. Viewing followed by funeral service at 10am on Monday, August 5, 2013 at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th Street, New York City.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve has spent heavily to buy bonds to reduce long-term rates, but rates are actually higher than when it started.

headline.main: What the Nation Got for $800 Billion
headline.print_headline: What the Nation Got For $800 Billion

docs.abstract: Anna Bernasek Data Points column notes that Federal Reserve has spent $800 billion buying bonds since Sept 2012 to reduce long-term rates, but rates are actually higher than when it started; points out that for that money Fed could have given every homeowner in nation $10,000 loan at near-zero rate of interest, with greater economic benefit.
docs.snippet: The Federal Reserve has spent heavily to buy bonds to reduce long-term rates, but rates are actually higher than when it started.

byline.original: Karen Barrow, Pedro Rafael Rosado, Kriston Lewis and Abe Sater

docs.abstract: This week, the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman offers a refreshing take on the taco, beginning with two delicious summer salsas.
docs.snippet: This week, the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman offers a refreshing take on the taco, beginning with two delicious summer salsas.

headline.main: Saying Good Riddance to the Clean-Plate Club

docs.abstract: What do you say when your children tell you they’re “full”? As a family nutrition expert, no matter what’s still on the plate and what was eaten, I say nothing at all.
docs.snippet: What do you say when your children tell you they’re “full”? As a family nutrition expert, no matter what’s still on the plate and what was eaten, I say nothing at all.

docs.lead_paragraph: A plan by House leaders to cut $40 billion from the food stamp program threatens to derail efforts by the House and Senate to complete a farm bill before agriculture programs expire on Sept. 30.

headline.main: G.O.P. Push to Slash Food Stamps Puts Farm Bill in Jeopardy
